ResponseText: As Congress gets arroganter and arroganter, and their reelection rate hovers around 99%, it behooves us to start thinking seriously about restarting the drive for a Congressional Term Limits Amendment. Which is precisely the objective of my fledgling website, tenurecorrupts.com. One of the pages on the site is devoted to the various kinds of amendments which might be employed by our activists, and to devise the most effective wording of a proposed amendment. The particular wording I am putting forth (besides specifying 3 terms for the House and 2 terms for the Senate) contains the phrase exempts current incumbents as long as they are successfully reelected. The obvious objective here is to make the amendment totally unobjectionable to all the incumbents who have to vote on the proposed amendment. I conceived this weasel wording back in the days when successful incumbent reelections were running in the low 90 percentiles, and I figured that if it took a few years after ratification for term limits to effectively take place, it was a worthwhile tradeoff. Imagine my horror when I discovered that the 2004 reelection rate was 99%! At that rate, replacing only 1%, or 5 or 6 incumbents every 2 years, it would take about 50 elections, or 100 years, to get only one-half of Congress term limited! Of course, the skeptic will say that 2004 was an anomaly. Future reelection rates are not likely to be so highly successful! Yeah, sure. In the face of electoral historical trends, I would be willing to bet that 99% is gonna be far more frequent than 90%. I think the lazy, indifferent voter who votes mostly on name recognition is here to stay for a long time, sustaining the status quo and the entrenched incumbencies. Remember, when elections are even reasonably close, it is the fraction of stand-pat name recognition voters who keep the incumbents in place. And they will always be with us. It is gonna take term limits to change this situation. So lets get crackin! I'm Nelson Lee Walker, and I believe our Congress needs Term Limits. www.tenurecorrupts.com
